sources.name: CLMS N2K Monitoring, time series

meta.description: Detailed land cover and land use information for 55 thematic classes in selected Natura2000 sites for the 2018 reference year. The dataset has a Minimum Mapping Unit (MMU) of 0.5 ha and a Minimum Mapping Width (MMW) of 10 m and is available as vector data.

sources.name: Growing Stock Volume, time series - 2017 to 2023
CLMS NDVI 300m 10 daily time series - 2020 to present

meta.description: NDVI is an indicator of the greenness of the biomes. Every 10-days estimates are available in near real time at global scale in the spatial resolution of about 300 m from July 2020 to the present.

sources.name: FAPAR 1km 10 daily v2 time series - 1999 to 2020

meta.description: Quantifies the fraction of the solar radiation absorbed by live plants for photosynthesis. Every 10-days estimates are available at global scale in the spatial resolution of about 1 km covering the period from 1999 to June 2020 from SPOT/VEGETATION and PROBA-V data.

sources.name: LST 5km 10 daily time series - 2021 to present

meta.description: Provides a statistical overview of the land surface temperature daily cycle for each 10-day compositing period and every geostationary sensor image pixel. The data are available at global scale in the spatial resolution of about 5 km and covers the period from January 2021 onwards with version 2.2.

sources.name: SWI 1km daily time series - 2015 to present

meta.description: Quantifies the moisture condition at various depths in the soil. Daily observations are available for the continental Europe in the spatial resolution of 1 km and with the temporal extent from January 2015 to present

sources.name: Peatland Classification

meta.description: The WorldPeatland method for mapping peatland extent involves the use of multitemporal composites of Sentinel-1 Ground Range Detected (GRD) radar data and Sentinel-2 surface reflectance imagery, trained using a reference peatland agreement map

sources.name: Peatland Classification, inverse mask

meta.description: The WorldPeatland method for mapping peatland extent involves the use of multitemporal composites of Sentinel-1 Ground Range Detected (GRD) radar data and Sentinel-2 surface reflectance imagery, trained using a reference peatland agreement map.  This layer shows the Saddleworth study area displayed as an inverse mask, so that the area where there is not peat is masked out allowing users to focus on looking at related layers where the peat exists.

sources.name: Peat Classification Agreement

meta.description: The agreement products are spatial extracts from multiple existing thematic datasets where the original developers have identified classes that label peatland or peatland-type land surfaces. These products combine independent peatland classifications to assess spatial consensus across different mapping approaches

sources.name: Trends in water level

meta.description: This dataset provides water level trend products (in mm/yr), including long-term trends derived from the S1S2SMAPL4 and SMAPL4 products, as well as human-induced water level trends estimated from their difference. Negative values indicate declining water levels, while positive values indicate rising levels. Long-term trends were calculated averaging yearly values from May through September in the Northern Hemisphere and over the full year in the tropical zone. or more reliable information, see "Trends in water level  high quality only" which only shows high quality grid cells.

sources.name: Trends in water level - high quality only

meta.description: This dataset provides water level trend products (in mm/yr), including long-term trends derived from the S1S2SMAPL4 and SMAPL4 products, as well as human-induced water level trends estimated from their difference. Negative values indicate declining water levels, while positive values indicate rising levels. Long-term trends were calculated averaging yearly values from May through September in the Northern Hemisphere and over the full year in the tropical zone. Only high quality grid cells are shown.

sources.name: Peatland Classification

meta.description: The WorldPeatland method for mapping peatland extent involves the use of multitemporal composites of Sentinel-1 Ground Range Detected (GRD) radar data and Sentinel-2 surface reflectance imagery, trained using a reference peatland agreement map

sources.name: Peat Classification Agreement

meta.description: The agreement products are spatial extracts from multiple existing thematic datasets where the original developers have identified classes that label peatland or peatland-type land surfaces. These products combine independent peatland classifications to assess spatial consensus across different mapping approaches

sources.name: Trends in water level

meta.description: This dataset provides water level trend products (in mm/yr), including long-term trends derived from the S1S2SMAPL4 and SMAPL4 products, as well as human-induced water level trends estimated from their difference. Negative values indicate declining water levels, while positive values indicate rising levels. Long-term trends were calculated averaging yearly values from May through September in the Northern Hemisphere and over the full year in the tropical zone. or more reliable information, see "Trends in water level  high quality only" which only shows high quality grid cells.

meta.description: This dataset provides water level trend products (in mm/yr), including long-term trends derived from the S1S2SMAPL4 and SMAPL4 products, as well as human-induced water level trends estimated from their difference. Negative values indicate declining water levels, while positive values indicate rising levels. Long-term trends were calculated averaging yearly values from May through September in the Northern Hemisphere and over the full year in the tropical zone. Only high quality grid cells are shown.
